lcInstruction.p: When writing with reuse in mind, make sure that your content is consistent, context-free, and generalized. By separating specific information from common information wherever possible, you can make sure that your common chunks of content are generic enough to be reused wherever needed.

To keep your content consistent, keep your topics short and granular. This will help maximize their reuse potential; a short topic with only one heading level can likely be reused in more places than a long topic that covers large amounts of information and goes several heading levels deep. Another way to increase consistency is to establish a style guide for tagging and usage, or to agree on usage if you don't have the time or budget to create a style guide. Finally, using a neutral voice can ensure consistency and make your topics more reusable. Limit your vocabulary and use of pronouns (particularly gender-specific ones), and avoid idioms and colloquialisms. A neutral, consistent voice will not only help with reuse, but also with localization.

Keeping your content free of context will also make it easier to reuse. When writing a topic, do not assume anything about the topic's context or the type of document map in which it will appear. This means avoiding the use of words such as "previous," "next," "earlier," and "later," as well as references to chapters or manuals. To make sure that references to other topics don't break when you reuse a topic in multiple places, always use relationship tables to create links instead of inline cross-references.

To make your writing more generalized, avoid the use of keywords or product dependencies wherever possible, and don't be too specific unless it's crucial. For example, if the same set of instructions applies to more than one product, don't include specific information about any one product in the steps. Avoid including gratuitous modifiers, such as number, size, or color, in your content. To strike a balance between making content generic for reuse and including necessary specifics, consider a table at the beginning of each deliverable that identifies certain product information. By providing that information up-front, you can then remove keywords from the content and rely on generic terms. Just like consistent content, generic content will not only help facilitate reuse, but will also better prepare you for localization. Reusing content also means that you will have fewer topics overall to translate, which will help reduce localization costs.
